clinicalDescription: Overview: Sometimes called - mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome. The disease causes swelling (inflammation) in the walls of medium-sized arteries throughout the body. It primarily affects children. The inflammation tends to affect the coronary arteries, which supply blood to the heart muscle.Presentation: high fever and peeling skin, extremely red eyes, swollen lymph nodes, joint pain, N/V. High white blood cell count and the presence of anemia and inflammation are signs of Kawasaki disease.Assessment: The condition most often affects kids younger than 5 years old. Need to rule out other diseases - no specific test available. Plan: Lower fever and inflammation and prevent heart damage. Gamma globulin (IV) and aspirin Prognosis: Treatable and most recover. Signs and symptoms slowly go away unless complications develop (can take up to 8 weeks to resolve).
